Most of German communal outfit Amon Düül's records were culled from a single
column3: epic jam session in the late 60s. What that means for listeners is a vast collection of material that
column5: never fails to delight. However
column6: since the ""band"" was quickly dwarfed by their mutinous former colleagues in Amon Düül II
column7: their reputation has tended to sag near areas suited more for slightly embarrassing little brothers and mix tapes you made in fifth grade: charming in their way
column8: but otherwise best not brought up in conversation. The most renown Amon Düül record
column9: Psychedelic Underground
column10: is indeed semi-fascinating in small doses
column11: but after a while
column12: my attention always lapses and the ragged (albeit inspired) performances begin to morph into a formless
column13: meandering goo.

column1: Judging the original Amon Düül against their more musically inclined successors
column2: or really any other band
column3: is probably unfair. They might very well hold up as well as any other hippie commune's drum circle cuts would
column4: and given the group's proximity to future krautrock legends should give them an edge. For this reason
column5: 1970's Para Dieswärts Düül is a better yardstick by which to measure their purely musical contributions. Rather than compiling still more hazy footage from group space-outs
column6: Amon Düül's third record (originally released on the legendary Ohr imprint) features actual songs
column7: very much in a free-folk vein
column8: but with English lyrics
column9: melodies and basic rhythms nonetheless. If you're hoping for a relatively earthbound intro to the band
column10: though
column11: this is still pretty out there-- and truthfully
column12: I still prefer modern groups like Charalambides to Amon Düül. Still
column13: Repertoire's new reissue of their most easily approachable record reveals that even though they could pull together an album of songs when need be
column14: they weren't necessarily songwriters
column15: or even a terribly interesting group of musicians.

column1: The lengthy ""Love Is Peace""
column2: which originally filled all of the LP's first side
column3: highlights the band's penchant for tuneless balladeering and the mileage one can wring from a single chord on captive acoustic guitars. The male vocalist (one of many musicians identified by name on the album
column4: but not according to what they played or sang) reminds me of a more stable Damo Suzuki
column5: though when the group harmonies enter during the ""chorus
column6: the band could be any number of psychedelic nature-folk units
column7: one part Donovan
column8: another Tom Bombadil. At one point
column9: everyone stops down to a series of echo-drenched guitar arpeggios that do lend the piece a spacy ambience
column10: but can't quite make up for the ensuing seven additional minutes of stream-of-consciousness poetry jamming.

column1: It's a shame
column2: because the rest of the record isn't bad. Originally
column3: the (almost) rocking ""Snow Your Thurst"" and genuinely alluring ""Paramechanische Welt"" made up the entire LP
column4: but the reissue includes the melancholy single ""Eternal Flow"" and an alternate
column5: electrified version of ""Welt"" entitled ""Paramechanical World"". Both ""Welt"" and ""World"" are examples of the kind of laid-back
column6: sunny folk that works as both psychedelic mantra music and straightforward folk-pop
column7: of the kind CSN&Y modified into outright pop and took to the bank. There isn't much in the way of lyrics
column8: but the moaning vocal melodies should be put in a time capsule as perfect examples of the deeply impassioned

column10: they had flower power down pat.

In this
column2: the age of the laptop
column3: mobility and fluidity have become watchwords of the modern electronic

column1: composer.  An idea is only as valid as the speed with which it can be documented and processed.  The art
of collage and cut-up have been present for a great deal longer in the literary and visual arts world; it's
only been with the recent advancement of computer technology and sound destroying/rebuilding software
plugins that music has been so democratized.  The last tethers to the recording studios of yore have been
severed
column2: and the musician is free to draw inspiration from sources all around him-- the terrestrially

column1: mundane can be elevated to the celestially sublime; all it takes is imagination and familiarity with one's
favorite software.
Nathan Michel is counted among the increasing number of these electronic alchemists.  Though somewhat
obscured by his higher profile compatriots at Tigerbeat6
column2: he's shown a remarkable penchant for daring yet

column1: highly listenable cut-and-paste.  There is
column2: of course
column3: the typical madcap grabs at popular music

column1: ghosts of club funk and the knowledge/acceptance of IDM form the skeleton of Michel's abstracted
architecture.  But what separates this recording from most of his contemporaries' efforts is his genuine
sense of wide-eyed wonder
column2: a childlike fascination with each new musical shape and juxtaposition that

column1: drifts by as the album unfolds. There's a palpable feeling of discovery on each track
column2: as though Michel

column1: himself were delighted by every gurgle
column2: pop and coo.

column1: Recently
column2: musicians operating within this genre have been increasingly unable to resist adding sung vocals

column1: often to weak and or/embarrassing result.  Nathan Michel is again an exception; his vocals occupy the same
relative space as any of the other delicate carnival attractions he's displayed.  I get the sense that he's
less concerned with why he should be suggesting these moods and textures
column2: and more appropriately with how

column1: they sound in context.  This golden rule
column2: which should be the common denominator of electronic exploration

column1: is often forgotten or temporarily ignored
column2: in favor of progress and novelty.
